titleStmt.title: A machine-readable profile of Ahwaz/Ahvaz Arabic
titleStmt.author: Bettina Leitner

sourceDesc.p: This is an original digital text

div.p: Bedouin-type gələt dialect; mixed variety with urban and rural features; strong Persian influence on the lexicon

Ahwāz is the capital city of the southwestern Iranian province of Khūzestān and situated alongside the river Kārūn. Of its 1.5 million inhabitants Arabs are the largest ethnic group, the second biggest group are Persians. There is also a small group of Sabeans living in Aḥwāz.
The city was apparently flourishing in pre-Islamic times but declined in the subsequent centuries to a village of about 10,000 inhabitants in the early 20th century.
Today many of the city’s inhabitants are working in the sugar cane and oil industry.

With the discovery of oil in the vicinity of Aḥwāz (1908) and during the time of the Iran-Iraq war, in which Aḥwāz was considered one of province’s the safer cities, many Arab people from the surrounding areas have moved to the capital city. This resulted in the penetration of many rural features into the originally urban dialect of Aḥwāz and thus reshaped its linguistic profile.

The first written document on the dialect of Aḥwāz is an unpublished and undated manuscript by D. Lorimer, in which he collected mainly lexical lists and verbal conjugation patterns. Further linguistic information on the dialect of Aḥwāz and other villages and cities in Khūzestān was gathered by Bruce Ingham, who published two articles (1973, 1976) on regional differences within Khūzestān including short texts, and a short grammatical analysis in EALL (2007). Ingham (1991) is a short study on sentence structure in Khuzestan Arabic.
